Award.AwardTitle: Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in two mini-conferences of the Atlanta Lecture Series in Graph Theory and Combinatorics, held November 12-13, 2016 and April 22-23, 2017 at Emory University and Georgia State University, respectively. Combinatorics and graph theory have undergone dramatic development in the past few decades. These two meetings in the Atlanta Lecture Series in Graph Theory and Combinatorics will feature the latest research developments and themes in the areas of structural graph theory, extremal graph theory, random graphs, percolation, hypergraphs, and extremal set theory. The series has become a major event for the combinatorics community in the southeast region and beyond, providing opportunities to strengthen collaborations among researchers and institutions within the southeast region of the United States.

Each conference features two one-hour lectures by a distinguished researcher, four one-hour lectures by established researchers mainly from the southeast region, and four 30-minute talks by early-career researchers and graduate students. The meetings provide opportunities for interaction among established researchers and rising stars; this award supports the attendance of graduate students, early-career researchers, and invited speakers. Additional information concerning financial support and the conference schedule is maintained at the lecture series website:
http://www.als.math.gatech.edu/

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the academic year 2016-2017, we proposed to organize two mini-conferences for Atlanta Lecture Series (ALS) in Combinatorics and Graph Theory.  The first mini-conference (ALS18) was successfully held at Emory University on the weekend of October 22-23, 2016 and the second one (ALS19) was held at Georgia State University  on the weekend of April 22-23, 2017.

ALS18 featured two 1-hour talks by Jeff Kahn, from Rutgers University. Also featured were four 1 hour talks by Esther Ezra,  Georgia Institute of Technology; Wesley Pegden, Carnegie Mellon University; Christian Reiher, University of Hamburg; and Joshua Zahl, University of British Columbia. These talks were supplemented by 25 minute talks by junior faculty and graduate students: Asaf Ferber, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Laszlo Miklos Lovasz, Massachusetts Institute of Technology;  Michael Tait, Carnegie Mellon University, and Yan Wang, Georgia Institute of Technology. 

ALS19 featured three 1-hour talks by three well-known mathematicians: Ronald Lewis "Ron" Graham, University of California San Diego; Daniela K\"uhn, University of Birmingham, England; and Deryk Osthus, University of Birmingham, England. Also featured were three 1 hour talks by Asaf Shapira, Tel-Aviv University; Wenan Zang, University of Hong Kong;  and Brendan Nagle, University of South Florida. These talks were supplemented by 25 minute talks by junior faculty and graduate students: Jessica McDonald, Auburn University; Louis DeBiasio, Miami University, Georgios Petridis, University of Georgia, and Clifford Smyth,  University of North Carolina Greensboro.

As proposed, these two mini-conferences featured some of the top combinatorists in the country and four other major researchers, as well as provided an opportunity for some younger faculty and graduate students to present their work. The conferences attracted a large number of participants from nearby institutions and provided support for some of them for attending. As such, we met all our goals stated in the proposal.
